channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israeli Girl Severely Wounded in Firebomb Attack in West Bank
item.description: The 11-year-old girl and her father were wounded when a firebomb was thrown at their car near the Jewish settlement of El Matan.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Jordan Warns Islamic State Militants Against Harming Captive Jordanian Pilot
item.description: The warning came as the pilot’s father implored the Islamic State to treat his son like a guest.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: Bits Blog: Uber C.E.O. Charged With Violating South Korea Transport Laws
item.description: Seoul prosecutors indicted Travis Kalanick, the ride-booking company’s chief executive, as well as its local unit and car-rental partner, on charges of violating taxi licensing laws.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: Travis Kalanick, chief executive of Uber, in Beijing last week.

item.title: Shabab Assailants in Somalia Ambush Christmas Dinner at African Union Base
item.description: At least five assailants were killed in the ambush, which began just as African Union officers were enjoying a Christmas Day respite.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: Letter From Europe: Shining Light on an Era's Darker Side
item.description: The death of Mandy Rice-Davies, who played a starring role in the Profumo Affair, evoked much more than a vicarious return to moments that defined their times.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Pope Francis, in Christmas Address, Focuses on Children’s Plight
item.description: Vast numbers of children today are victims of violence, objects of trade and trafficking, or forced to become soldiers, he said.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Hit Back Against a Foreign Intrusion: Christmas
item.description: As some Chinese enjoy the trappings of Western-style Christmas, and retailers enjoy some of their highest sales in late December, others are calling for bans on any celebrations.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Students in Changsha, Hunan Province, on Wednesday displayed banners reading "Resist Christmas. Chinese should not celebrate foreign festivals."

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Water From China’s South-North Transfer Project Flows to Beijing
item.description: Within days, Beijing’s faucets are expected to begin spewing water that has traveled hundreds of miles to the capital from Hubei Province via one of the world’s most ambitious, and controversial, engineering projects.
item.dc:creator: By KIKI ZHAO
item.media:description: The central, or second, route of the South-North Water Diversion Project began operations a year after the eastern route.

item.title: The Big Fix: Restored Forests Breathe Life Into Efforts Against Climate Change
item.description: Driven by a growing environmental movement and mounting pressure from Western consumers, corporate and government leaders are making a new push to slow the cutting of rain forests.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS

item.title: Pakistani Premier Announces Military Courts for Terrorism Cases
item.description: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif announced plans early Thursday to set up military courts to deal with terrorism cases after a deadly Taliban attack on a school in Peshawar last week.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Naples Journal: In Naples, Gift of Coffee to Strangers Never Seen
item.description: The Neapolitan tradition of “suspended coffee” — paying for two, drinking one and leaving the receipt for the other for a stranger — has spread around the world.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Storico Gran Caffè Gambrinus, which honors the Neapolitan tradition of the “suspended coffee.” The practice, which boomed during World War II, has found a revival in recent years.

item.title: Test for U.S. Shift on Cuba Is Whether Rights Improve
item.description: President Obama’s decision to restore full diplomatic relations with Cuba will be tested by whether Cuba honors promises to release political prisoners and to allow improvements in Internet access.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Yoani Sánchez, fourth from front on right, the director of an independent news website in Cuba, at a meeting of dissidents. Internet access is restricted in the country.

item.title: Oil’s Swift Fall Raises Fortunes of U.S. Abroad
item.description: A plunge in oil prices has sent tremors through the global political and economic order, helping the United States but pushing several big oil-exporting nations to the brink of financial crisis.
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Iranian oil workers Monday at a refinery south of Tehran. Facing a big budget hole, the government is offering to let men buy their way out of military service.

item.title: Sony Streams ‘The Interview’ on YouTube, Google Play and Xbox
item.description: In getting behind “The Interview,” Google and Microsoft joined what had become more a campaign to defend free speech against foreign intimidation than a business initiative.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL CIEPLY and BROOKS BARNES
item.media:description: Google offered “The Interview” in its Play store as well as on YouTube.

item.title: Mexicans Rally After a Priest Is Kidnapped
item.description: Roman Catholic clergy members and parishioners marched through Ciudad Altamirano in southern Mexico to protest a series of kidnappings, killings and robberies of priests.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: Labor Overhaul Advances
item.description: The Italian cabinet on Wednesday approved parts of a labor bill that Prime Minister Matteo Renzi said would revolutionize the country’s labor market and entice foreign investors.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Israel: Politicians Are Detained in a Broad Corruption Inquiry
item.description: More than 30 Israeli politicians and public figures have been detained for questioning in connection with a corruption probe, the police said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: World Briefing: China: Monk Burns Himself to Death in a Political Protest
item.description: A Tibetan monk died Tuesday after setting himself on fire near his monastery in Sichuan Province, Tibetan exile and advocacy groups said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Teenager Says Rebels Forced Her Into Suicide Attack
item.description: A 14-year-old girl who was arrested this month with explosives strapped to her body said Wednesday that her parents had offered her as a volunteer to participate in a suicide attack.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Vehicles Are Restricted in Anticipation of Attacks
item.description: Authorities have banned automobile traffic in two northeastern states, out of concern that Islamic extremists are plotting attacks over the Christmas holiday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
